as supplemented  and ordinances subsequently adopted by the city council the source of each section is included in the history note appearing in parentheses at the end thereof the absence of such a note indicates that the section is new and was adopted for the first time with the adoption of the use of the comparative tables appearing in the back of this volume the reader can locate any section of the 1984 as supplemented and any subsequent ordinance included herein the chapters of the been conveniently arranged in alphabetical order and the various sections within each chapter have been catchlined to facilitate usage notes which tie related sections of the which refer to relevant state law have been included a table listing the state law citations and setting forth their location within the included at the back of this volume system the chapter and section numbering system used in this the same system used in many state and local government codes each section number consists of two parts separated by a dash the figure before the dash refers to the chapter number and the figure after the dash refers to the position of the section within the chapter thus the second section of chapter 1 is numbered 12 and the first section of chapter 6 is 61 under this system each section is identified with its chapter and at the same time new sections can be inserted in their proper place by using the decimal system for amendments for example if new material consisting of one section that would logically come between sections 61 and 62 is desired to be added such new section would be numbered 615 new articles and new divisions may be included in the same way or in the case of articles may be placed at the end of the chapter embracing the subject and in the case of divisions may be placed at the end of the article embracing the subject the next successive number shall be assigned to the new article or division new chapters may be included by using one of the reserved chapter numbers care should be taken that the alphabetical arrangement of chapters is maintained when including new chapters page numbering system the page numbering system used in this a prefix system the letters to the left of the colon are an abbreviation which represents a certain portion of the volume the number to the right of the colon represents the number of the page in that portion in the case of a chapter of the the number to the left of the colon indicates the number of the chapter in the case of an appendix to the the letter immediately to the left of the colon indicates the letter of the appendix the following are typical parts of codes of ordinances which may or may not appear in this this time and their corresponding prefixes charter cht1 charter comparative table chtct1 code cd land development regulations appendix ldra1 franchises f1 code comparative tables cct1 land development regulations comparative tables ldrct1 state law reference table slt1 charter index chti1 code index cdi1 land development regulations index appendix a ldrai1 franchises index fi1 indexes the indexes have been prepared with the greatest of care each particular item has been placed under several headings some of which are couched in lay phraseology others in legal terminology and still others in language generally used by local government officials and employees there are numerous cross references within the indexes themselves which stand as guideposts to direct the user to the particular item in which the user is interested looseleaf supplements a special feature of this publication is the looseleaf system of binding and supplemental servicing of the publication with this system the publication will be kept up to date subsequent amendatory legislation will be properly edited and the affected page or pages will be reprinted these new pages will be distributed to holders of copies of the publication with instructions for the manner of inserting the new pages and deleting the obsolete pages keeping this publication up to date at all times will depend largely upon the holder of the publication as revised pages are received it will then become the responsibility of the holder to have the amendments inserted according to the attached instructions it is strongly recommended by the publisher that all such amendments be inserted immediately upon receipt to avoid misplacing them and in addition that all deleted pages be saved and filed for historical reference purposes acknowledgments this publication was under the direct supervision of alyce florida special acts 1969  was adopted at a referendum held on   and is included herein for the convenience of the users of this chapter title and the description of the city boundaries have been omitted from this printing the original arrangement and numbering system have been maintained but a uniform system of capitalization and indention like that used in the of this volume has been employed amendments to the original enactment have been worked into their proper places and history notes indicating the origin of the amendatory section and the date of the referendum where applicable have been added the absence of such a history note indicates that the section was derived unamended from the original enactment corrections and explanatory words are indicated by brackets   the original charter laws of florida ch 69879 was in existence in that form on  at that time cities were granted home rule powers by the florida constitution in article viii  2b as implemented by fs ch 166 the municipal home rule powers act fs  4 states that municipalities may exercise all powers for municipal governmental corporate or proprietary purposes not expressly prohibited by the constitution general or special law and repealed all limitations on the exercise of that power in any charter or special act in existence on  except for those provisions which may only be amended by referendum or special act as indicated regarding the following areas 1 creation or existence of the municipality  2 establishment of the form of government  3 grants of extraterritorial power or power affecting areas which include lands outside the municipality which must be by general law or special act  4 establishment of terms of elected officials and the manner of their election  5 distribution of power among elected officials  6 matters relating to appointive boards  7 any rights of municipal employees therefore those sections of the charter not one of the areas listed by operation of fs   were converted to ordinances and any limitations on the exercise of the home rule powers in said charter were repealed on the effective date of the act  however if any section of a charter was amended by referendum after  then it must be subsequently amended by referendum as stated in attorney general opinion 75223 therefore the provisions of the charter were either converted to an ordinance repealed as a limitation on the exercise of home rule powers or is one of the categories which may only be amended by referendum state law reference municipal home rule powers act fs  16601 et seq article i  general provisions creation of government there is hereby created a municipal corporation under the name of the city of melbourne in the county of brevard state of florida which city shall have all powers possible for a city to have under the constitution and laws of the state of florida as fully and completely as if specifically enumerated in this charter in addition to any powers specifically so enumerated construction of powers  retention of former powers the powers of the city shall be construed liberally in favor of the city and the specification of particular powers shall not be construed as limiting in any way the general powers possessed by the city the city shall have implied and incidental powers to exercise those powers enumerated herein or granted by general law the city of melbourne shall have and may exercise all the powers heretofore possessed by the several municipalities abolished pursuant to this charter and by any commission agency or board exercising any governmental function or powers within such municipalities to the extent not inconsistent with this charter as such powers existed on the date this charter takes effect this section shall control whether any such powers were created granted or possessed pursuant to special act municipal charter or otherwise editors note the editor has deleted the last sentence of  102 concerning urban renewal powers as posing a limitation repealed pursuant to fs   abolition of existing governmental agencies subject to the referendum provisions of section 8092 herein section 809 has been repealed which determine the conditions under which this charter becomes valid and determine which municipalities are included therein and upon the effective date of this charter and as provided therein the existing municipal govts governments of any of the following named municipalities which are included in the validated charter existing municipal government of eau gallie in brevard county florida is hereby abolished every commission agency or board exercising any governmental function or powers within such municipality is similarly abolished the city of melbourne shall succeed to own and possess all property property rights interest uncollected taxes dues claims judgments and choses in action held or owned by such municipality commissions agencies or boards the city shall have exercise and enjoy all the rights immunities powers benefits privileges and franchises now or formerly possessed or held by said abolished municipality commissions agencies or boards either individually or collectively editors note this section was editorially corrected to delete indialantic melbourne melbourne beach palm bay palm shores west melbourne and melbourne village as only melbourne and eau gallie merged and became the city of melbourne former obligations no obligation or contract of the governmental agencies which term includes municipalities abolished pursuant to this act or any of them including bonds heretofore issued shall be impaired or avoided by this charter but all debts obligations and contracts of the abolished governmental agencies shall pass to and be binding upon the city of melbourne as hereinafter provided  and all debts obligations and contracts heretofore legally and validly incurred or let by said governmental agencies are hereby ratified validated and confirmed as reference intergovernmental programs fs ch 163 article ii  city council footnotes  2  state law reference municipal home rule powers act fs ch 166 general powers and duties all powers of the city shall be vested in an elected council except as otherwise provided by law or by this charter the council shall provide for the exercise by the city of its municipal powers and for the performance of all duties and obligations imposed on the city by law state law reference home rule powers fs ch 166 composition and qualifications 1 a the council shall consist of seven 7 members including the mayor elected by the qualified voters of the city at large as hereinafter provided members of the city council shall be residents of the city and shall have been residents for at least one 1 year prior to the date of qualifications for office additionally members of the city council other than the mayor shall be residents of and maintain their principal place of domicile in the district for which they seek to qualify and shall have been residents of said district for at least six 6 months prior to the date of qualification for office all city council members shall be at least eighteen 18 years of age and shall have the qualifications of a city elector the office of a council member shall be forfeited whenever a member ceases to possess the foregoing qualifications or when a member accepts any other elective public office b neither a council member or the mayor may qualify for or serve more than two 2 complete consecutive terms and the portion of an unexpired term occurring by reason of a vacancy notwithstanding the foregoing an elected city official such as a council member who has served the maximum time in office as permitted by this paragraph may qualify for and be elected to serve in a different city elected office such as mayor any city elected official who resigns within one 1 year three hundred sixtyfive 365 days   one 1 year before the end of the second consecutive term of office shall be prohibited from qualifying as a candidate for the same council seat in the next regular city election this paragraph shall be applicable to any council member or the mayor who subsequent to the election held on  has served for two 2 complete consecutive terms and which terms have been served in full after  2 any qualified elector of the city who meets the foregoing qualifications may qualify for a council seat by presenting to the city clerk a petition signed by twentyfive 25 qualified city electors and by paying a filing fee during the qualifying period as established from time to time in the city ordinances and said elector shall submit concurrently therewith a sworn statement of his or her name address occupation and willingness to serve if elected until otherwise provided by city ordinance the filing fee shall be fifty dollars $5000 laws of fla ch 70807  3   10301973   21019811131981   781986   1141997   8282001 editors note was approved at herein mayor the mayor shall qualify and run for office for a term of four 4 years as hereinafter provided he shall be a voting member of the council the presiding officer of the council and the titular head of the city the mayor is recognized as head of the city government for ceremonial purposes for the purposes of service of civil process and for purposes of military law the mayor shall execute all instruments to which the city is a party as the council may direct unless otherwise provided by this charter or by law the council may elect from its membership a vicemayor who shall serve as mayor in the absence of the mayor laws of fla ch 70807  3   72219861141986 editors note was approved by voters at a general election on  this amendment shall not take effect until the election for mayor in 198 at which time the mayor elected shall serve a term of four 4 years as provided for herein compensation the salary of council members together with the manner of payment shall be established by ordinance and shall be compatible with salaries as portrayed by the florida league of municipalities for cities of comparable size and form of government no increase in salary shall become effective until the commencement of terms of members elected at the next regular city election the council may provide that members shall receive their actual and necessary expenses incurred in the performance of their duties prohibition against employment no council member shall hold any other city office or city employment during the term for which he was elected to the council vacancies on the council a vacancy shall occur upon the death resignation removal from office as authorized by law or forfeiture of office of a council member when such vacancy occurs the remaining council members shall select by the affirmative vote of not less than a majority of the remaining membership a person to fill the vacancy such a person shall meet the qualifications for council members specified in this charter and shall serve until the next general municipal election if the council shall fail to fill a vacancy within thirty 30 days after it occurs or whenever three 3 or more vacancies shall occur at the same time the city clerk shall immediately call a special election to fill the vacancy or vacancies the council may provide for filling council vacancies by special election in such other circumstances as it deems appropriate council to be judge of members qualifications the council shall be the judge of the election and qualifications of its members and for such pure shall have the power to subpoena witnesses and require to production of evidence but the decision of the council in any such case shall be subject to review by the courts council meetings the council shall meet regularly at the city hall or other municipal building at such times and places as it may prescribe but in no event less than twice each month all official meetings of the council shall be open to the public special meetings limited to the subjects specified in the call may be convened by the mayor or any three 3 council members or the city manager upon at least twentyfour 24 hours notice to each member and to at least one news medium servicing the municipality emergency meetings may be called with a minimum of twenty four 24 hours notice state law reference open meetings law fs   legislative procedure four 4 members of the council shall constitute a quorum but a smaller number may adjourn from day to day and may compel the attendance of absent members in such manner and under such penalties as the council may prescribe no action of the council except raising a quorum shall be valid or binding unless adopted by the affirmative vote of at least four 4 members of the council the council shall determine its own rules and order of business and shall provide for the keeping of a journal of its proceedings the journal shall be a public record and shall be open to public inspection the council may prescribe for expulsion of disorderly persons from its meetings ordinances and resolutions every proposed ordinance or resolution shall be introduced in the final written or printed form required for adoption the enacting clause of ordinances shall recite be it enacted by the city of melbourne florida editors note the editor has deleted the last sentence of this paragraph on adoption of ordinances as preempted by fs   concerning uniform standards for adoption of ordinances a proposed ordinance may be amended at either meeting however no ordinance shall be amended at the second or later reading so as to change its intent without a further reading at least one week later the council may provide for public hearings or for the publication of notice concerning the subject matter of any proposed ordinance or amendment ordinances and resolutions shall become effective upon passage unless otherwise specified therein every ordinance and resolution shall upon final passage be authenticated by the presiding officer and the city clerk or deputy clerk and shall be recorded and published as the council shall prescribe state law reference uniform minimum mandatory procedure for adoption of ordinances and resolutions fs   codification and distribution of ordinances and related matter within two 2 years after the effective date of this charter and at least once every five 5 years thereafter the council shall provide for the preparation of a general codification of all city ordinances resolutions having the force of law and such codes of technical regulations and other rules or regulations as the council may specify the council may include in the general codification the city charter charter amendments and relevant state constitutional and statutory provisions upon compilation the general codification shall be known and cited as the city melbourne florida copies of the be furnished to city officers and public offices for reference as required shall be placed in public libraries of the city and shall be made available for purchase by the public at a reasonable price fixed by the council emergency ordinances notwithstanding the provisions of the foregoing sections the council may enact emergency ordinances to meet serious public emergencies affecting the welfare of the city or its inhabitants an emergency ordinance shall be introduced in the form and manner prescribed for ordinances generally except that it shall be plainly designated as an emergency ordinance and the conditions constituting such emergency shall be stated therein  it may be adopted with or without amendment at the meeting at which introduced emergency ordinances shall expire thirty 30 days after enactment unless sooner specified therein state law reference procedure for adoption of emergency ordinances fs  b codes of technical regulations the council may adopt any standard code of technical regulations by reference thereto in an adopting ordinance adopting ordinances shall be enacted as herein provided for ordinances generally any adopted code of technical regulations shall be made available to the public as the council shall provide state law reference florida building fs  55373 article iii  general city administration selection and removal of city manager the council shall select a city manager who shall be the chief administrative and executive officer of the city the city manager shall be selected solely on the basis of administrative and executive qualifications his salary shall be fixed by the council the manager may be removed by majority vote of the council acting city manager the city manager may designate by letter filed with the city clerk an acting city manager to perform his duties during his temporary absence or disability if the manager fails to make such designation or if the council disapproves his designation the council may by resolution appoint another officer to serve until the manager returns or the disability ceases in any case the acting city manager shall be qualified as administrative officer of the city powers and duties of the manager the city manager shall be responsible to the council for the administration of all city affairs and to that end subject to the provisions of this charter he shall have power and is required to 1 appoint and when necessary for the good of the city suspend or remove all city employees except those appointed by the city council he may authorize the head of a department agency or office to exercise such powers within the department agency or office 2 fix the salary of the city officers and employees within the pay schedules of the city council except those appointed by the city council 3 supervise the administration of all city departments agencies and offices 4 endorse all instruments in writing in which the city is interested signify his acknowledgment of the substance thereof as he deems appropriate and execute contracts on behalf of the city unless the council shall otherwise provide 5 prepare and submit an annual city budget to the council together with such other fiscal reports and programs as the council may require  and be responsible for the administration of the city budget and other fiscal programs upon their adoption 6 advise the council concerning the financial condition and future needs of the city making such recommendations as from time to time he deems desirable 7 make such reports concerning the operation and administration of city government as the council may require 8 perform such other duties as may be prescribed in this charter or required by the council consistent with this charter attendance of manager at council meetings the city manager shall attend all council meetings and may participate without vote in discussions of the council except that the council may exclude the manager from any session in which his conduct is in issue administrative units of city government the council by ordinance may establish and prescribe the composition duties and functions of city departments agencies and offices in addition to those created by this charter in the same manner departments agencies or offices so created may be abolished or consolidated or one or more duties or functions of units may be discontinued or reassigned or additional duties or functions may be assigned organization of administrative units two 2 or more departments agencies or offices may be headed by the same individual  and the head of a unit may serve as the head of one or more divisions thereof subject to the power set forth in the preceding section or unless otherwise provided in this charter the head of any unit may distribute the duties and work of the unit among such divisions and division heads or assistants as he deems appropriate and as the city manager shall approve initial departments and offices until otherwise provided pursuant to this charter there shall be as administrative units of the city those separate offices and departments prescribed in the following seven 7 sections office of the city manager the city manager shall be the administrative head of the municipal government and shall be responsible for the efficient administration of all departments and may be the head of such department or departments as the council may from time to time by ordinance provide office of the city clerk there shall be a city clerk who shall be appointed by and serve under the administrative direction of the city manager the clerk shall attend all city council meetings unless excused  shall keep the journal of its proceedings  shall authenticate by his signature and record in full in a book to be kept for that purpose all ordinances and resolutions he shall attest to and countersign by his signature all contracts bonds and other instruments as required by law and shall perform such other duties required by this charter and as may be assigned by the city manager the city clerk may appoint deputies to carry out requirements of this office at the discretion of the city manager b 10301973   8141979 state law reference public records law fs ch 119  procedures for adoption of ordinances and resolutions fs   office of the city attorney this office shall be held by a city attorney appointed by the council to serve at the pleasure of the council the salary of the city attorney shall be fixed by the council the city attorney shall be legal advisor and attorney to the officers of the city in matters affecting the city or relating to their official duties  prosecute and defend in on behalf of the city all civil actions in which the city is a party as the council may require  prepare and endorse written instruments in which the city is concerned as the council may require  and perform other duties as the council may require or as may be prescribed by general state law consistent with this charter and with ordinances or resolutions of the council one or more assistants may perform any duties of the city attorney the city attorney and his assistants shall be lawyers admitted to and having authority to practice in all courts of the state as well as the federal district court  8141979 police department the police department under a chief of police shall be responsible for the enforcement of federal and state laws and city ordinances fire department the fire department under a fire chief shall be responsible for city firefighting and fire prevention activities fire risk inspections and elimination of fire hazards department of fiscal affairs finance the department of fiscal affairs finance under a director who shall be city auditor shall have charge of financial administration of the city the department shall supervise the collection of all monies due the city including all tax collection and collection of license fees and other fees and revenues  supervise the disbursement of city funds  maintain a general accounting system for the city government and units thereof  compile fiscal estimates and prepare fiscal reports as may be required by the council or manager  supervise all tax assessments  be custodian of all funds belonging to or under the control of the city or city governmental units department of public works the department of public works under a director shall have charge of the general administration of city property the department shall be responsible for all public grounds buildings works utilities automotive equipment and machinery  supervise construction and maintenance of streets sidewalks sewerage and similar facilities on behalf of the city  maintain parks playgrounds cemeteries and similar facilities operated by the city engineering and planning department the engineering and planning department shall be under the supervision of a registered florida engineer who shall serve full time and have such assistants and planners as may be deemed necessary the department shall perform any and all planning and engineering required by the city its departments and boards including but not limited to preparing master city development plans official street zoning and other maps for the city supervising the design and engineering of public facilities of the city verifying that same are properly built altered or maintained and such other engineering and planning duties as may be assigned by the council such department shall include at least one professionally trained planner holding a college degree in the field of planning and he shall serve as the chief administrative officer for any and all land use regulation programs within for or on behalf of the city and as advisor to the council and all city boards concerning same this section shall not prevent the employment of such additional professional engineering and planning service as may be deemed necessary for any particular project subject to council approval council not to interfere in administrative affairs neither the council nor any of its members shall direct or request any personnel action by the city manager or any of his subordinates nor interfere in any manner with the internal administration of city government except for the purpose of inquiry or investigation the council and its members shall deal with the city administrative service solely city manager and neither the council nor its members shall give directions or make requests to any subordinates of the city manager either publicly or privately this section shall not preclude the council from making known to the city manager its views concerning personnel actions and the internal administration of city government participation in political campaigns editors note this section has been limitation which was repealed by fs  4 personnel system and policy the personnel rules and regulations of the city of melbourne as adopted and amended from time to time by the city council shall constitute the personnel policies and procedures pertaining to employment of city employees within the city administrative service the city administrative service shall be defined to include all employees of the city below the level of department head department heads shall be so designated by the city manager in all events selection retention and advancement of employees in the city shall be based on merit fitness and performance free of personal and political considerations  8141979 independent audits the council shall designate qualified certified public accountants who shall make an independent audit of accounts and financial transactions of the city government and the several units thereof as of the end of each fiscal year the council may provide for more frequent audits of the city government a copy of each audit shall be filed with the legislative auditor of the state of florida editors note this section has been superseded by fs 4 fiscal years financial reports appropriations and audits state law reference annual audit required fs  21832 ethics the following ethics shall apply to all officers and employees of the municipality whether elected or appointed paid or unpaid 1 no officer or employee of the municipality shall knowingly a engage in any business or transaction or have a financial or other personal interest direct or indirect which is incompatible with the proper discharge of his official duties or would tend to impair his independence of judgment or action in the performance of his official duties b engage in or accept private employment or render services for private interests when such employment or service is incompatible with the proper discharge of his official duties or would tend to impair his independence of judgment or action in the performance of his official duties c disclose confidential information concerning the property government or affairs of the governmental body by which he is employed without proper legal authorization or use such information to advance the financial or other private interests of himself or others d accept any valuable gift whether in the form of service loan thing or promise from any person firm or corporation which to his knowledge is interested directly or indirectly in any manner whatsoever in business dealings with the governmental body by which he is employed  provided however that any such officer or employee who is a candidate for public office may accept campaign contributions and services in connection with any such campaign e represent private interests in any action or proceeding against the governmental body by which he is employed f vote or otherwise participate in the negotiation or the making of any contract with any business or entity in which he has a financial interest g any officer or employee of the municipality who shall have any private financial interest directly or indirectly in any contract or matter pending before or within any department of the municipality shall disclose such private interest to the council any councilman who has a private interest in any matter pending before the council shall disclose such private interest on the records of the council editors note the editor has deleted the second part of the compound verb phrase in the last sentence on disqualification from voting  see fs   and  on voting conflicts h no officer or employee of the municipality shall use property owned by such governmental body for personal benefit convenience or profit except in accordance with policies promulgated by the council i no current or former member of the city council shall be eligible to apply for or be employed by the city in any paid position whatsoever for a period of two 2 years after the last date of service by the member on city council 2 the city council shall provide by ordinance for a system whereby all candidates for elective office in the municipality shall report to the city clerk all expenses and contributions of said election campaign such reports shall be available to the public  3221994 state law reference campaign financing fs ch 106  ethics for public officers and employees fs   et seq establishing a parks and recreation department the department of parks and recreation under the director shall have the responsibility of planning and operating a recreation program for the city including planning and operation of parks  civil defense rescue and disaster relief a civil defense rescue and disaster relief committee shall be and hereby is established this committee shall be composed of the city manager police chief fire chief and two 2 citizens appointed by the council the committee shall be responsible for formulating plans and acquiring equipment and supplies which are necessary for the preservation of life and property during time of natural or manmade disaster the committee shall further be responsible for formulating plans and acquiring abolished and former county areas pending adoption of a master land use plan for the city of melbourne 1 division of municipality into districts for purposes of regulation the city council may divide the corporate area of the municipality into districts of such number shape and area as may be deemed best suited to carry out the purposes of this section and within such districts it may regulate and restrict the erection construction reconstruction alteration repair or use of buildings structures or land all such regulations shall be uniform for each class or kind of building throughout each district but the regulations in one district may differ from those in other districts 2 purposes in view in making regulations regulations shall be made in accordance with a comprehensive plan and designed to lessen congestion in the streets  to secure safety from fire panic and other dangers  to promote health and the general welfare  to provide adequate light and air  to prevent the overcrowding of land  to avoid undue concentration of population  to facilitate the adequate provision of transportation water sewerage schools parks and other public requirements such regulations shall be made with reasonable consideration among other things to the character of the district and its peculiar suitability for particular uses and with a view to conserving the value of buildings and encouraging the most appropriate use of land throughout said municipality 3 municipality to provide procedure  regulations restriction or boundary not effective until after public hearing thereon parties in interest and citizens shall have an opportunity to be heard at least fifteen 15 days notice of the time and place of such hearing shall be published in a newspaper of general circulation 4 shall be filled for the unexpired term of any member whose term becomes vacant 8 proceedings of board of adjustment the board shall adopt rules in accordance with the provisions of any ordinance adopted pursuant to this chapter article meetings of the board shall be held at the call of the chairman and at such times as the board may determine such chairman or in his absence the acting chairman may administer oaths and compel the attendance of witnesses all meetings of the board shall be open to the public the board shall keep minutes of its proceedings showing the vote of each member upon each question or if absent or failing to vote indicating such fact and shall keep records of its examinations and other official actions all of which shall be immediately filed in the office of the board and shall be a public record 9 appeals appeals to the board of adjustment may be taken by any person aggrieved or by any officer or bureau of the governing body of said municipality affected by any decision of the administrative officer such appeal shall be taken within a reasonable time as provided by the rules of the board by filing with the officer from whom the appeal is taken and with the board of adjustment a notice of appeal specifying the grounds thereof the officer from whom the appeal is taken shall forthwith transmit to the board all the papers constituting the record upon which the action appealed from was taken 10 stay of proceedings an appeal stays all proceedings in furtherance of the action appealed from unless the officer from whom the appeal is taken certifies to the board of adjustment after the notice of appeal shall have been filed with him that by reason of facts stated in the certificate of stay would in his opinion cause imminent peril to life and property in such case proceedings shall not be stayed otherwise than by a restraining order which may be granted by the board of adjustment or by a court of record on application on notice to the officer from whom the appeal is taken and on due cause shown 11 hearing of appeal  notice required the board of adjustment shall fix a reasonable time for the hearing of the appeal give public notice thereof as well as due notice to the parties in interest and decide the same within a reasonable time upon the hearing any party may appear in person or by agent or by attorney 12 powers of board of adjustment the board of adjustment shall have the following powers a to hear and decide appeals where it is alleged there is error in any order requirement decision or determination made by an administrative official in the enforcement of this chapter or of any ordinance adopted pursuant thereto b to hear and decide special exceptions to the terms of the ordinance upon which such board is required to pass under such ordinance c to authorize upon appeal in specific cases such variance from the terms of the ordinance as will not be contrary to the public interest where owing to special conditions a literal enforcement of the provisions of the ordinance will result in unnecessary hardship and so justice will be done 13 decision of board in exercising the abovementioned powers such board may in conformity with the provisions of this chapter article reverse or affirm wholly or partly or may modify the order requirement decision or determination appealed from and may make such order requirement decision or determination as ought to be made and to that end shall have all the powers of the officer from whom the appeal is taken the concurring vote of five 5 members of the board shall be necessary to reverse any order requirement decision of any such administrative official or to decide in favor of the applicant on any matter upon which it is required to pass under any such ordinance or to effect any variation in such ordinance 14 review circuit court any person or persons jointly or severally aggrieved by any decision of the board of may notify the city clerk after the meeting for inclusion in the minutes if the city manager city clerk or city attorney is unable to attend the meeting the official shall make prior arrangements for attendance by their respective assistants at the meeting d cancellation of meeting if there is no business or a paucity of business as determined by the mayor or in the mayors absence the vicemayor to be transacted at a regular meeting or if it appears that a quorum is likely not to be obtained at said meeting the mayor or in the mayors absence the vicemayor may cancel the meeting  provided that no more than one regular meeting in any month may be cancelled any special meeting may be cancelled by the individual calling the meeting    592000   5232006 charter reference city council meetings  209 presiding officer  duties pursuant to section 204 of the charter the presiding officer of the city council shall be the mayor or in the mayors absence the vicemayor the presiding officer shall preserve strict order and decorum at all regular and special meetings of the city council the presiding officer must state every question coming before the city council before a vote is taken announce the decision of the city council on all subjects and decide all questions of order subject however to an appeal to the city council in which event a majority vote of the city council shall govern and conclusively determine such question of order the presiding officer must vote on all questions said presiding officers name being called last unless the presiding officer has a conflict of interest or is otherwise excused from voting the presiding officer must sign all ordinances and resolutions adopted by the city council during said individuals presence in the event of the absence of the mayor the presiding officer shall sign ordinances or resolutions as then adopted    592000 charter reference mayor is presiding officer  204 call to order  temporary presiding officer the mayor or in his absence the vicemayor shall call the city council to order at the time prescribed in the agenda for that meeting in the absence of the mayor and vicemayor the city clerk or the city clerks assistant shall call the city council to order whereupon a temporary chair shall be elected by the members of the city council present upon the arrival of the mayor or vicemayor the temporary chair shall immediately relinquish the chair upon the conclusion of the item immediately before the city council    592000 roll call before proceeding with the business of the city council the city clerk or city council shall be open to the public during regular meetings the business of the city council shall be taken up for consideration in generally the following order 1 invocation 2 pledge of allegiance 3 roll call 4 proclamations and presentations 5 approval of minutes of previous meeting 6 city managers report 7 public comments the time limit provision in section 232 does not apply to this item 8 unfinished business 9 new business with engineering or construction contracts in excess of $5000000 appearing first and the consent agenda appearing second 10 petitions remonstrances and communications 11 adjournment    592000 reading of minutes unless a reading of the minutes of a city council meeting is requested by a majority of the city council such minutes may be approved without presiding may move second and debate from the chair subject only to such limitations of debate as are imposed by these rules on all members and shall not be deprived of any of the rights and privileges of a council member by reason of his acting as the presiding officer b getting the floor  improper references to be avoided every member desiring to speak must address the chair and upon recognition by the presiding officer shall confine comments to the question under debate avoiding all personalities and indecorous language c interruptions a member once recognized must not be interrupted when speaking unless it is to call said member to order or as herein otherwise provided if a member while speaking is called to order the member will cease speaking until the question of order is determined and if in order the member will be permitted to proceed d privilege of closing debate the council member moving the adoption of an ordinance or resolution has the privilege of closing the debate e motion to reconsider a motion to reconsider any action taken by the city council may be made only on the day such action was taken it may be made either immediately during the same session or at a recessed or adjourned session thereof such motion must be made by a council member on the prevailing side but may be seconded by any member and may be made at any time and have precedence over all other motions or while a member has the floor  such motion shall be debatable a member on the prevailing side may also make a motion to reconsider and leave pending which motion to reconsider and leave pending will then be considered at the next regular meeting any member may second a motion to reconsider and leave pending f remarks of council member  when entered in minutes a council member may request presiding officer the privilege of having an abstract of said council members statement on any subject under consideration by the city council entered in the minutes if the city council consents thereto such statement shall be entered in the minutes g synopsis of debate  when entered in minutes the clerk may be directed by the presiding officer with consent of the city council to enter in the minutes a synopsis of the discussion on any question coming regularly before the city council h rules of order meetings will be conducted substantially in accordance with roberts rules of order newly revised the mayor shall enforce parliamentary rules for the government of the city council when in session modifications of such rules may be adopted by vote of the city council from time to time no alterations of a rule or adoption of a new rule shall take place without the consent of foursevenths of the members of the city council and upon one months notice prior to the vote any rule of procedure may be suspended by the unanimous vote of the city council for the meeting then in session    592000 addressing the city counciltime limit a each person who wishes to meanings ascribed to them in this subsection except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning city attorney means the city attorney for the city of melbourne or said city attorneys designee court means and refers to 1 a judicial tribunal created by of the florida constitution of 1968  2 a judicial tribunal created by title 28 united states 28 usc 1482  3 a trial or appellate court or administrative law tribunal of any state or territory of the united states of america other than florida  4 an action pending before an administrative law judge appointed pursuant to fs  12065  or 5 an action pending before a federal administrative law judge appointed pursuant to 5 usc 3105 major claim means and refers to the following types of claims against the city whether or not the claim has matured into a lawsuit filed in court the settlement of which claim would 1 require the payment of in excess of $20000000 to any one person or which when totaled with all other claims or judgments paid by or for the benefit of the city arising out of the same incident or occurrence exceeds the sum of $30000000 by the city an insurance carrier utilized by the city which carrier is making payment pursuant to an insurance policy issued to the city or a third party acting on behalf of the city  2 require the payment of any claim for which the city is not fully insured other than payment of an insurance deductible  3 require the taking of or refraining from the taking of any action by the city which the city manager does not have authority to undertake  or 4 result in the issuance of a development order as defined in fs   workers compensation claims pursuant to fs ch 440 shall not be construed to be a major claim minor claim means and refers to the following types of claims against the city whether or not the claim has matured into a lawsuit filed with an administrative or judicial tribunal the settlement of which claim or payment of a judgment for said claim 1 requires payment excluding insurance policy deductible amounts of not more than $20000000 to any one person or which when totaled with all other claims or judgments paid by or for the benefit of the city arising out of the same incident or occurrence does not exceed $30000000 by an insurance carrier utilized by the city which carrier is making payment pursuant to an insurance policy issued to the city or a third party acting on behalf of the city and which will not require the taking of or refraining from the taking of any action by the city which the city manager has not been previously delegated authority to undertake  2 results in payment by the city of any amount equal to or less than the amount of a city insurance policy deductible amount and which will not require the taking of or refraining from the taking of any action by the city which the city manager has not been previously delegated authority to undertake  3 a claim for workers compensation benefits pursuant to fs ch 440  or 4 a claim the settlement of which is consistent with authority to settle previously delegated to the city manager or his designee b lawsuit settlement requiring city council approval except for any claim for damages or other compensation excluding insurance policy deductible amounts that the citys insurance carrier or other third party has agreed to be responsible for the payment of as a result of a settlement no major claim for damages compensation or other relief shall be the subject of a prelitigation settlement or an outofcourt or courtapproved settlement without the approval of the city council with regard to the settlement of any lawsuit or other claim against the city other than for compensation or damages that requires action or an omission to act that can only be agreed to by the city council no settlement may occur without the approval of the city council c lawsuit settlements not requiring city council approval a minor claim for damages compensation or other relief may be the subject of a prelitigation settlement or an outofcourt or courtapproved settlement without the approval of the city council but only upon the approval of the city manager or his designee the settlement by the city manager or his designee of any minor claim or workers compensation action shall bind the city to the same extent as if the city council had approved the same and authority to effectuate resolution of minor claims is hereby delegated to the city manager or the city managers designee d settlement negotiations and mediation the city attorney has the full power and authority to negotiate or mediate a settlement of any claim for damages or other relief on behalf of the city the city attorney has the full power and authority to recommend a settlement to the city council of any major claim or other pending or threatened lawsuit seeking to have actions taken by the city or seeking to have the city to refrain from taking actions the city attorney has the full power and authority to recommend a settlement to the manager or said city managers designee of any minor claim one of the chief purposes of this delegation of authority is to comply with the requirements of rule d florida rules of civil procedure in negotiating or mediating claims the city attorney will coordinate any negotiations or settlement with the citys risk manager and insurance carrier if any    592000 state law reference tort claims fs  76828 ordinances resolutions motions and contracts a preparation of ordinances no ordinance shall be prepared for presentation to the city desires to appeal a final decision made by the planning and zoning board may file a written notice of appeal within 30 days of the final order being rendered and filed in the records of the community development department such appeal must specify the grounds for the appeal the city council shall make a determination on the appeal within 30 days of such applicationpetition b the following procedures shall apply to the appeal process outlined above as used in this section the term rendition means the issuance of a written order by the planning and zoning board effective upon the date that a signed original is filed in the records of the secretaryclerk to the planning and zoning board a copy of said written order must be hand delivered or mailed postage prepaid by us certified mail to the person requesting the order the letter must be mailed or hand delivered on the date of filing in the records of the secretaryclerk to the planning and zoning board 1 the notice of appeal shall be filed with the city clerk with a copy to the planning and zoning board secretary within 30 days of the rendition of the planning and zoning boards decision the city clerk shall stamp the date of filing on the notice of appeal so that compliance with the 30day filing requirement can be quickly and easily ascertained 2 if the date of rendition of the planning and zoning boards decision and the date of appeal are within 30 days of each other a determination shall be made that the appeal has been timely filed if the two documents were not filed within 30 days of each other the appeal was not timely filed the city council shall then issue an order dismissing the appeal and no further action is required 3 within 30 days after the filing of the notice of appeal the appellant shall be required to have a court stenographer prepare a verbatim transcript of the planning and zoning board hearing at which the final order being appealed was issued the preparation of the verbatim transcript is the responsibility of the appellant and will be at the expense of the appellant within 30 days after the filing of the notice of appeal the appellant may also file a written argument explaining why the planning and zoning boards decision should be reversed within 30 days after the filing of any written argument by the appellant the community development director may file a written argument with the city clerk for the city council 4 the planning and zoning board secretary shall assemble all documents from the planning and zoning boards hearing together with a copy of the boards final order which constitutes the record the transcript shall be forwarded to the city council at the same time the record is forwarded to the city council the city council shall not rehear the entire matter although oral arguments with regard to the appeal may be heard by the city council the city council will determine whether the planning and zoning board made a decision inconsistent with the law or this   whether the boards decision is supported by substantial competent evidence  and whether due process was afforded to the parties if the planning and zoning boards decision is inconsistent with the law or the   if the planning and zoning boards decision is not supported by substantial competent evidence  or if procedural due process was not afforded to the parties then the city council may reverse the decision and return the matter to the planning and zoning board for further action consistent with the city councils action if the planning and zoning board made a decision consistent with the essential requirements of the law and the code supported by substantial competent evidence and procedural due process was afforded to the parties even if the decision is not the best or more desirable decision the city council shall affirm the boards decision    3252008 secs 23322350  reserved division 9  golf courses advisory board appointment of members and terms of office a the golf and $3500000 processed by the procurement division local business means the vendor is either a localcity or localcounty business localcity business means the vendor has 1 a valid business tax receipt issued by the city at least one year prior to the solicitation of a formal quotebid for which the business may seek local vendor preference  and 2 a physical business address located within the city in an area zoned for the conduct of such business from which the vendor is operating or performing its business and at which it maintains fulltime employees localcounty business means the vendor has 1 a valid business tax receipt issued by the county at least one year prior to the solicitation of a formal quotebid for which the business may seek local vendor preference  and 2 a physical business address located within the county from which the vendor is operating or performing its business and at which it maintains fulltime employees nonlocal business means any vendor that does not meet either the definition of localcity business or localcounty business as defined in this section b establishment as local business to establish that a vendor is a local business a vendor shall provide written documentation of compliance with the definitions for each such local business as defined in subsection a of this section at the time of submitting a formal quotebid post office boxes are not verifiable and shall not be used for the purpose of establishing the required physical business address a vendor that misrepresents the local preference status of its firm in a formal quotebid submitted to the city shall lose the privilege to claim local preference status for a period of two years c local preference in purchasing and contracting the city shall give award preference to a local business in the purchase of commodities personal property general services professional services and the purchase of or contract for construction or renovation of public works or other public improvements by means of formal quote or competitive bid in the following manner 1 competitive quotebid each formal competitive quotebid solicitation shall clearly identify how the price order of the quotesbids received will be evaluated and determined 2 local award if the initial lowest quotebid is submitted by a qualified and responsive local business there is no further local preference given 3 localcity preference a under a competitive quotebid solicitation when a qualified responsive responsible nonlocal business submits the lowest price quotebid and a quotebid submitted by one or more responsive responsible localcity businesses is within five percent of the price submitted by the nonlocal business then each of the responsive responsible local businesses within five percent shall have the opportunity to submit an offer to match the price submitted by the nonlocal bidder a price match document must be received within five business days after issuance b if the initial lowest localcity business submits an offer that matches the lowest nonlocal quotebid and the two vendors are similarly qualified and responsive bidders then the award shall be made to the localcity business c if the initial lowest localcity business declines or is unable to match the lowest nonlocal quotebid then the option to do so moves to the next initial lowest localcity business and so on that is a similarly qualified and responsive bidder 4 localcounty preference a at such time that there is no localcity business within five percent of the lowest bid or all eligible localcity bidders decline nonlocal quotebid and the two vendors are similarly qualified and responsive bidders then the award shall be made to the localcounty business c if the initial lowest localcounty business declines or is unable to match the lowest nonlocal quotebid then the option to do so moves to the next initial lowest localcounty business and so on that is a similarly qualified and responsive bidder 5 no local award should none of the local bidders be willing to price match the lowest nonlocal quotebid then the lowest nonlocal bid shall be awarded the purchase or contract 6 unit pricing if a local business against the nonlocal quotebid pricing in accordance with the quotebid solicitation requirement 7 tie quotesbids in the event of a tie between the initial quotebid of two or more local businesses the secs 26482667  reserved article x  special activity permits purpose the intent of the city council in adopting this article is to recognize that there are certain special or unique activities not recognized in the which provide for an economically viable community special activities whether held on private property or public property may require the provision of city services andor a temporary waiver from this article provides the regulatory framework for the processing of special activity permits and authorizes the development of administrative policies and procedures to process such permits the city is committed to balancing the citys interests in protecting public health and safety article with the first amendment rights of special activity permit applicants it is the intent of the city council that the review of applications for special activity permits be limited to contentneutral time place and manner conditions and restrictions and that the city clerk and relevant city departments coordinate with the city attorney to ensure that city policies and procedures in interpreting and applying this article are consistent with applicable first amendment principles    592000 used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning admission street event means an event held on city property where an admission is charged for access to the event area annual permit means a special activity permit or permit agreement issued by the city clerk for qualified recurring special events that remains effective for up to a 12month period identified in the permit or permit agreement at the time of issuance block party means a noncommercial organized public gathering for the purpose of having a party or other social recreational or similar assemblage composed substantially of neighbors in a predominantly residential area on a public rightofway street sidewalk or alley where no admission is charged for access to any portion of the event area  merchandise food and beverages are not offered in exchange for money  and city services with the exception of traffic control devices are not required business promotion means an event that does not require city services held at a place of business on private property for the sole purpose of promoting the business located on the property a promotion may include but not be limited to placement of a balloon banner inflatable sign temporary sign or tent  sales andor distribution of food and beverages  and use of sound amplification city property means any public street sidewalk place property easement rightofway structure or facility owned dedicated controlled or otherwise under the jurisdiction and control of the city city sponsored event means a community based nonprofit event that is free to the public and appeals to the broadest segment of the community director means the city code compliance director or his designee fire chief means the city fire chief or his designee life safety management document means the written plan defined by nfpa 1 national fire protection association code that is required with each application for an outdoor event that is fenced or gated has open seating and an expected peak attendance of 6000 or more outdoor seasonal sales means items associated with a season seasonal sales may include sparklers pumpkins christmas trees and holiday decorations the term outdoor seasonal sale is narrowly defined and may not include a broad category such as gifts crafts or household items police chief means the city police chief or his designee special activity or special event means a public or private event conducted outside that is characterized by its limited duration infrequent occurrence or seasonal nature and by the fact that permanent improvements are not made to the site  or an event where it can be anticipated that the number of persons attending the event will exceed the onsite parking available at the event area  or an event where it can be reasonably expected that services will be required beyond those that are regularly provided by the city such as police services traffic control crowd control code compliance fire andor emergency medical services street closures or other municipal services that may be necessary to service the event  or an event that involves displays or activities that will impinge on any adjacent area including amplified sound athletic events carnivals circuses concerts fireworks high intensity lighting musical groups parades runs street events and walkathons special activity application means the form provided by the city clerk for the purposes of processing a special activity special activity application fee means the fee an applicant is required to pay before a special activity application can be processed special activity permit means a permit that is issued by the city clerk for an event conducted on private property or public property not under city ownership or control special activity permit agreement means an agreement that is issued by the city clerk and approved by the city manager for an event that is held on city property or an event where the cost of city services and equipment is estimated to be $500000 or more special activity permitting procedures means the administrative procedures prepared by the city clerk as amended from time to time pertaining to the issuance of a special activity permit or permit agreement submittals means additional documents that are required as part of the special activity review process examples include but are not limited to site plan tent form mobile vending form police department employment services request form trash and recycling plan parking plan accessibility plan security plan lighting plan life safety management document copy of alcohol permit issued by the state and certificate of insurance temporary structure means any structure used during a special event with a primary purpose of protection from the elements such as a tent stage platform concession trailer and similar items temporary structures do not include vehicles tables chairs portable restrooms and trash or garbage receptacles traffic engineering means the city engineer or his designee year means the period january 1 inclusive    592000   3272012   892016 events held on city property a liability insurance the applicant the individual or other legal entity holding the activity will provide and maintain at all times during the event without cost or expense to the city a commercial general liability cgl insurance policy this policy of insurance will have a per occurrence coverage trigger and cover the applicant the individual or other legal entity holding the activity and its or their employees for any and all claims demands and expenses whatsoever including defense and causes for action for general damages bodily injury and property damage arising out of or to the extent caused by negligent acts or omissions intentional misconduct of the applicant the individual or other legal entity holding the activity and its or their employees and volunteers these insurance requirements shall not relieve or limit the liability of the applicant the individual or other legal entity holding the activity the following minimum insurance requirements shall be provided 1 occurrence basis all policies except professional liability insurance and workers compensation shall be written on an occurrence and not a claimsmade basis and at a minimum shall cover the applicant organizers sponsors and all event volunteer workers and volunteer vendors 2 coverage and deductible amounts the coverage amount for the cgl policy shall not be less than $100000000 per occurrence and in the aggregate and may be met by a combination of underlying and umbrella policies so long as in combination the limits equal or exceed those stated the deductible amount for the cgl policy shall not be more than $300000 per occurrence 3 additional insured the cgl policy shall be endorsed to add the city of melbourne as an additional insured 4 evidence of insurance in addition to a certificate of insurance that lists the specific event that is being covered the city requires proof that the policy has been endorsed by adding the city as additional insured for the duration of the special event to satisfy this requirement the applicant may provide a copy of the actual policy endorsement page or written communication from the insurance agent to the insurance company directing that the policy be endorsed by adding the city as additional insured 5 insurance companies all insurance shall be effected under valid and enforceable policies issued by insurers qualified to do business in the state or surplus line carriers on the state insurance commissioners approved list of companies qualified to do business in the state all insurance carriers and surplus line carriers shall be rated b+ with a financial size category of vii or better by am best company b alcohol in addition to the insurance requirements in subsection a of this section additional insurance is required if alcohol will be sold served or consumed within the event area applicants or parties serving alcohol who are in the business of manufacturing distributing selling serving or furnishing alcoholic beverages must obtain or have full liquor liability insurance with a per occurrence and aggregate limit of not less than $100000000 with a deductible amount of not more than $300000 applicants or parties serving alcohol who are not in the business of manufacturing distributing selling serving or furnishing alcoholic beverages must obtain or have host liquor liability insurance with a per occurrence and aggregate limit of not less than $100000000 with a deductible amount of not more than $300000 an applicable liquor liability insurance policy must be maintained in full force at all times during the event without cost or expense to the city this policy of insurance will be required to cover the applicant the individual or other legal entity holding the activity and its or their employees or volunteers for any and all claims demands and expenses whatsoever including defense and causes arising from or related to the furnishing sale consumption or serving of alcoholic beverages of any type as defined in fs chs 561565 these insurance requirements will not relieve or limit the liability of the applicant the individual or other legal entity holding the activity and allowing alcohol to be consumed sold or served all entities licensed to serve alcohol within the event area shall provide proof of insurance to the city    3272012   892016 be presented to the city clerk in interpreting this the city clerk shall be first guided by the plain meaning of the words and terms in this second by the intent expressed herein the city clerk shall make an interpretation based on review of the code as a whole and not by taking specific words or clauses in isolation b the provisions of this article shall be held to be minimum requirements adopted for the protection of the public health safety morals and general welfare whenever the requirements of this article conflict with the requirements of any other lawfully adopted rule regulation or ordinance the most restrictive shall prevail    3272012 appeals  city not responsible for costs a a person aggrieved by a decision of the city clerk in the denial of a special activity permit may appeal to the city manager the appeal must be made in writing within not more than ten days following the denial it shall include an explanation by the applicant as to any factual errors the city made in processing the application b if an application or permit is not approved the city shall not be responsible for any costs incurred by the applicant or his affiliates    3272012 authority to revoke permit after a special activity permit or permit agreement has been issued the city may revoke the permit either in whole or in part or revoke authorization for certain permitted activities if the applicant does not meet the conditions of the permit or permit agreement if a portion of the event is not in compliance the city may close that portion of the event until compliance is achieved incorporation of recitals a purpose it is the purpose of this chapter to regulate sexually oriented businesses and adult entertainment establishments in order to promote and protect the public health safety good order morals and general welfare of the citizens of the city to establish reasonable and uniform regulations of adult entertainment establishments and sexually oriented businesses within the city the provisions of this chapter have neither the purpose nor effect of imposing an unreasonable limitation or restriction on the content of any lawful communicative materials including sexually oriented materials similarly it is not the intent nor effect of this chapter to unreasonably restrict or deny access by adults to sexually oriented materials protected by the first amendment or to deny access by the distributors and exhibitors of sexually oriented entertainment protected by the first amendment to their intended market neither is it the intent nor effect of this chapter to condone or legitimize the distribution of obscene or otherwise illegal material b findings based on evidence concerning the adverse secondary effects of adult uses on the community presented in
